etymologies: Middle English (in traverse (sense 3 of the verb)): from Old French traverser, from late Latin traversare; the noun is from Old French travers (masculine), traverse (feminine), partly based on traverser

definitions: travel across or through
shortDefinitions: travel across or through

definitions: extend across or through

examples.text: a moving catwalk that traversed a vast cavernous space

shortDefinitions: extend across or through

definitions: cross a hill or mountain by means of a series of sideways movements from one practicable line of ascent or descent to another

examples.text: I often use this route, eventually traversing around the cliff

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: cross rock face by means of series of sideways movements from one practicable line

definitions: ski diagonally across (a slope), with only a slight descent

examples.text: ski patrol workers traverse the slope

shortDefinitions: ski diagonally across slope, losing only little height

definitions: consider or discuss the whole extent of (a subject)

examples.text: he would traverse a number of subjects and disciplines

shortDefinitions: consider whole extent of

definitions: move (something) back and forth or sideways

examples.text: a probe is traversed along the tunnel

shortDefinitions: move back and forth or sideways

definitions: turn (a large gun or other device on a pivot) to face a different direction.
shortDefinitions: turn large gun device on pivot to face different direction

definitions: deny (an allegation) in pleading

examples.text: the plaintiff must assert certain facts which, if traversed, he would be put to prove

shortDefinitions: deny allegation in pleading

definitions: oppose or thwart (a plan).
shortDefinitions: oppose or thwart

definitions: an act of traversing something

examples.text: high-level walks in the Dolomites often involve steep, exposed climbs, traverses, and descents

shortDefinitions: act of traversing something

definitions: a hill or mountain where traversing is necessary

examples.text: a narrow traverse made lethal by snow and ice

shortDefinitions: rock face where traversing is necessary

definitions: a movement following a diagonal course made by a skier descending a slope

examples.text: I make long gentle traverses down the steepest sections

shortDefinitions: movement following diagonal course made by skier descending slope

definitions: a zigzag course followed by a ship because winds or currents prevent it from sailing directly toward its destination.
shortDefinitions: zigzag course taken by ship because winds or currents prevent it from sailing directly towards its destination

definitions: a part of a structure that extends or is fixed across something

examples.text: there were three jewels in the traverse of the cross and four in the body

shortDefinitions: part of structure that extends or is fixed across something

definitions: a gallery extending from side to side of a church or other building.
shortDefinitions: gallery extending from side to side of church

definitions: a mechanism enabling a large gun to be turned to face a different direction

examples.text: they had been practicing firing at multiple targets, using the power traverse

shortDefinitions: mechanism enabling large gun to be turned to face different direction

definitions: the sideways movement of a part in a machine.
shortDefinitions: sideways movement of part in machine

definitions: a single line of survey, usually plotted from compass bearings and chained or paced distances between angular points.
shortDefinitions: single line of survey, usually plotted from compass bearings

definitions: a tract surveyed by traversing.
shortDefinitions: area surveyed with traverse

definitions: a pair of right-angled bends incorporated in a trench to avoid enfilading fire

examples.text: he crept up and threw a grenade over the traverse

shortDefinitions: pair of right-angled bends incorporated in trench

definitions: (of a curtain rod) allowing the curtain to be opened and closed by sliding it along the rod.
shortDefinitions: allowing curtain to be opened and closed by sliding it along rod
